verse: King David said this to the whole assembly:

The officials of fathers’ houses, the officials of the tribes of Israel, and the officers of the thousands and of the hundreds made their offerings to the officials who were in charge of the king’s work.

They gave for the service of the house of God five thousand talents and ten thousand darics of gold, ten thousand talents of silver, eighteen thousand talents of bronze, and one hundred thousand talents of iron.
Anyone who possessed stones gave them to the treasury of the House of the Lord, which was under the control of Jehiel the Gershonite.
The people rejoiced over their willing giving, since with an undivided heart they had offered freely to the Lord. King David also was very joyful.
David blessed the Lord in the presence of the entire assembly. He said:

David said to the whole assembly, “Now bless the Lord your God.” So all the assembly blessed the Lord, the God of their fathers. They bowed and stretched out flat on the ground before the Lord and the king.

They offered sacrifices to the Lord. On the next day they offered burnt offerings to the Lord (one thousand bulls, one thousand rams, one thousand lambs), their drink offerings, and sacrifices in abundance for all Israel.
They ate and drank before the Lord on that day with great joy. They made Solomon, the son of David, king a second time. They anointed him as the ruler for the Lord and Zadok as the priest.
Solomon sat on the throne of the Lord as king in the place of David his father. He prospered, and all Israel obeyed him.
All the officials, the strong warriors, and also all the sons of King David pledged loyalty to Solomon the king.
The Lord made Solomon extremely great in the presence of all Israel. He gave him kingly majesty, such as had not been bestowed upon any king before him in Israel.
David son of Jesse had been king over all Israel.
He was king over Israel for forty years, in Hebron for seven years and in Jerusalem for thirty-three years.
He died at a good age, full of days, riches, and honor. Then Solomon his son reigned as king in his place.
The acts of King David from first to last are written in the records of Samuel the seer, the records of Nathan the prophet, and the records of Gad the seer,
including everything about his kingship, his mighty deeds, and the events that happened during his time, to him, to Israel, and to the kingdoms of the other lands.
